description: Established in 1819, Alabama is renowned for the U.S. Space & Rocket Center in Huntsville, showcasing the state’s contributions to space exploration.
Founded in 1959, Alaska’s claim to fame is Denali National Park, where North America’s tallest peak offers awe-inspiring wilderness views.
Since 1912, Arizona has captivated visitors with the Grand Canyon, a world-famous marvel of breathtaking geological formations and colors.
Added to the Union in 1836, Arkansas is beloved for Hot Springs National Park, a destination blending natural beauty with historic allure.
Since 1850, California has been famous for the Golden Gate Bridge, an iconic San Francisco landmark recognized around the globe.
Colorado, admitted in 1876, is celebrated for Rocky Mountain National Park, offering stunning alpine lakes and rugged mountain landscapes.
One of the original 13 colonies, established in 1788, Connecticut is noted for Mystic Seaport, a window into America’s maritime heritage.
The first state, established in 1787, Delaware is famed for Rehoboth Beach, featuring a lively boardwalk and scenic Atlantic coastline.
Since 1845, Florida has enchanted visitors with Walt Disney World in Orlando, bringing magical adventures to guests of all ages.
Georgia, a state since 1788, is best known for the Savannah Historic District, a charming area with cobblestone streets and antebellum homes.
Joining the Union in 1959, Hawaii is celebrated for Waikiki Beach on Oahu, where white sands and surf combine for a tropical paradise.
Since 1890, Idaho’s pride has been Shoshone Falls, dubbed the “Niagara of the West” for its spectacular, roaring cascades.
Established in 1818, Illinois is known worldwide for Millennium Park in Chicago, where art and architecture meet in a modern oasis.
Indiana, since 1816, is synonymous with the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, a historic raceway adored by motorsport fans.
Brought into statehood in 1846, Iowa is cherished for the Field of Dreams Movie Site, a tribute to baseball in America’s heartland.
Founded in 1861, Kansas stands out for Monument Rocks, ancient chalk formations that offer a glimpse into prehistoric times.
Kentucky, one of the earliest states from 1792, boasts Mammoth Cave National Park, home to the world’s most extensive cave system.
Established in 1812, Louisiana shines with the French Quarter in New Orleans, a vibrant area famous for its music, food, and nightlife.
Since 1820, Maine has been known for Acadia National Park, where rugged coastline meets lush forests, attracting nature enthusiasts.
Joining the Union in 1788, Maryland’s highlight is the National Aquarium in Baltimore, a top destination for marine lovers.
One of the original states from 1788, Massachusetts is celebrated for the Freedom Trail in Boston, a journey through rich American history.
Michigan, added in 1837, is famous for Mackinac Island, known for its charming, car-free atmosphere and Victorian architecture.
Since 1858, Minnesota’s pride has been the Mall of America, a massive complex for shopping, dining, and entertainment.
Founded in 1817, Mississippi honors its past with Vicksburg National Military Park, preserving pivotal Civil War history.
Admitted in 1821, Missouri is well-known for the Gateway Arch in St. Louis, symbolizing the westward expansion of America.
Joining the Union in 1889, Montana is celebrated for Glacier National Park, with its breathtaking landscapes and pristine wilderness.
Nebraska, established in 1867, is famed for Chimney Rock, a historic landmark along the Oregon Trail.
Founded in 1864, Nevada is world-famous for the Las Vegas Strip, a hub of casinos, nightlife, and entertainment.
Joining the Union in 1788, New Hampshire boasts the White Mountain National Forest, perfect for outdoor adventure.
As a state since 1787, New Jersey draws visitors to the Atlantic City Boardwalk, a bustling seaside attraction.
Since 1912, New Mexico has been famous for Carlsbad Caverns, where unique cave formations attract explorers.
New York, established in 1788, is globally recognized for the Statue of Liberty, a beacon of freedom in New York Harbor.
Founded in 1789, North Carolina is admired for Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a biodiverse haven.
Since 1889, North Dakota’s pride is Theodore Roosevelt National Park, showcasing rugged landscapes and wildlife.
Ohio, admitted in 1803, is famous for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland, celebrating music history.
Established in 1907, Oklahoma highlights the National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum, honoring its frontier spirit.
Since 1859, Oregon’s natural wonder is Crater Lake National Park, home to the deepest lake in the U.S.
Pennsylvania, a founding state from 1787, holds the Liberty Bell, an enduring symbol of American independence.
Founded in 1790, Rhode Island is celebrated for The Breakers, a mansion reflecting the opulence of the Gilded Age.
South Carolina, since 1788, is known for Charleston’s Historic District, rich with antebellum charm.
Added in 1889, South Dakota is iconic for Mount Rushmore, where presidents are carved into the Black Hills.
Joining the Union in 1796, Tennessee is famed for Great Smoky Mountains National Park, shared with North Carolina.
Texas, a state since 1845, is remembered for the Alamo, a significant landmark in its fight for independence.
Founded in 1896, Utah is distinguished by Zion National Park, known for its impressive red rock formations.
Vermont, since 1791, is famous for Stowe Mountain Resort, a top destination for winter sports and scenic views.
Virginia, established in 1788, is notable for Colonial Williamsburg, offering an immersive journey into early American life.
Since 1889, Washington is best known for the Space Needle in Seattle, offering panoramic views of mountains and cityscape.
Founded in 1863, West Virginia is home to New River Gorge Bridge, an iconic spot for outdoor adventure.
Admitted in 1848, Wisconsin is famous for the Wisconsin Dells, with unique rock formations and water attractions.
Since 1890, Wyoming’s natural treasure is Yellowstone National Park, famed for its geysers and geothermal wonders.
Established as the nation’s capital in 1790, Washington DC is home to iconic landmarks such as the U.S. Capitol and the Lincoln Memorial.
